Glencore has been ordered to hand over documents and records to US regulators related to its operations in Nigeria, the Democratic Republic of Congo and Venezuela dating as far back as 2007, sending its shares tumbling 12 per cent.

The Swiss-based mining and trading group led by billionaire Ivan Glasenberg said on Tuesday that it had received a subpoena from the US Department of Justice to produce documents with respect to compliance with the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act and US money laundering statutes. The records related to the company’s activities in Nigeria, Venezuela and the DRC, a source of near constant headaches for Glencore.

“Glencore is reviewing the subpoena and will provide further information in due course as appropriate,” the company said.

Following press reports in May of an impending UK Serious Fraud Office
(SFO) investigation into Glencore’s dealings in the DRC. this move by the DOJ is not all that surprising. Nevertheless, the stock is likely to take a hit as the market digests the potential implications of an investigation or
potential fine on the company. The stock had only recently recovered from its recent string of DRC related issues so investors will be feeling exasperated by this latest development.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

At the time of writing, Glencore’s shares were down ~9% on the news (FTSE 100 down 1.2%). We believe this is an overreaction based on the information available so far. The largest-ever criminal foreign bribery fine brought against a company by the DOJ was the recent $3.5bn fine against Odebrecht and its petrochemical subsidiary, Braskem. Prior to that, the largest fine paid was $772mn by French power and transportation company, Alstom SA, in late 2015. Glencore has just lost ~$5.9bn in market value, implying a fine almost 70% larger than the Odebrecht fine.

While it is clearly hard to quantify potential outcomes, we note investigations typically take 4+ years to complete and looking at precedents the maximum fine issued to any company under a Foreign Corrupt Practices Act investigation was $965m to Telia in 2017. A fine equal to that would equate to 5p/sh for Glencore vs a 41p share price decline today. We note BHP was found guilty of a FCPA breach relating to the 2008 Olympics and settled for $25m after a 6-year investigation. For context, we note that a 1% higher discount rate for GLEN would, ceteris paribus, reduce our NPV by 45p to 352p/sh. Overall we believe the share price move today is severe and, while Glencore warrants a discount for ongoing risks, a c.70% discount to peers on FY18E/19E P/E (ex-marketing at 15x P/E) feels extreme, in our view.

We would expect that Glencore will use all legal means to defend itself and would highlight that there are no formal charges at this stage. challenges facing the company. The company continues to screen very inexpensive at spot 3.4x EV/EBITDA vs. peers at 5.0x (excluding Congo), and we continue to prefer the relative commodity mix over what we see as a volatile coming 6 months for the sector.

McBride has confirmed the sale of its Personal Care Liquids business for £12.5m this is a positive development as the business was generating a loss of £2.8m on sales of £56m in the current year. The company has also delivered a trading update indicating that sales have been marginally weaker than anticipated along with higher than expected losses in its PCA business. This will result in adj PBT being below the low end of the range for FY 2018e at c.£31.7m (c.9% d/grade to NSe); for FY 2019e adj PBT is expected to c.£38.8m (c.5% d/grade to NSe). Near term the downgrade is a clear disappointment but longer term we see the emergence of a much stronger and more focused business as being a positive development. We reiterate our Buy rating but lower our TP from 210p to 170p.

Trading in May was below expectations, with France still tough (on branded discounting) but Germany (recent Danlind acquisition) ahead. H2 LFL sales in Household are ahead 3.8% relative to negative 3.4% in H1. Input costs have remained stable since January, relative to 4% inflation in H1. We view that as a surprising and reassuring result in the face of broader petrochemical inflation. Operating costs in the final quarter have however been higher than expected due to temporary additional distribution and warehousing costs and some inefficiencies.
